content.title: Risk Assessment Fundamentals
content.description: Master the concepts of risk identification, assessment, and management

cards.back: The potential for loss, damage, or destruction of assets as a result of a threat exploiting a vulnerability
Risk = Threat × Vulnerability × Impact (or Likelihood × Impact)
Any potential danger to information or systems (e.g., hackers, malware, natural disasters)
A weakness in a system that can be exploited by threats (e.g., unpatched software, weak passwords)
The amount of risk an organization is willing to accept in pursuit of its objectives
Qualitative uses descriptive scales (High/Medium/Low), Quantitative uses numerical values and calculations ($)
Annual Loss Expectancy = Single Loss Expectancy (SLE) × Annual Rate of Occurrence (ARO)
Implementing controls to reduce the likelihood or impact of a risk

1. Accept (tolerate)
2. Mitigate (reduce)
3. Transfer (insurance/outsource)
4. Avoid (eliminate)
The risk that remains after controls have been implemented
A document that lists identified risks, their assessment scores, owners, and treatment plans
The specific maximum risk that an organization is willing to accept around a specific objective
A safeguard or countermeasure designed to reduce risk (preventive, detective, or corrective)
Technical (firewalls), Administrative (policies), Physical (locks)
The risk level before any controls are applied

1. Identify assets
2. Identify threats
3. Identify vulnerabilities
4. Analyze risk
5. Determine treatment
A grid showing likelihood vs impact to categorize risks (typically 3x3 or 5x5)
Reasonable steps taken to identify and manage risks before making decisions
An alternative control used when the primary control cannot be implemented
Shifting risk to a third party (e.g., cyber insurance, outsourcing)
